text: Neither shall thy name any more be called Abram, but thy name shall be Abraham; for a father of many nations have I made thee.
text_kjv: Neither shall thy name any more be called Abram, but thy name shall be Abraham; for a father of many nations have I made thee.
text_niv: No longer will you be called Abram; your name will be Abraham, for I have made you a father of many nations.
text_esv: No longer shall your name be called Abram,  but your name shall be Abraham,  for I have made you the father of a multitude of nations.
text_nlt: What’s more, I am changing your name. It will no longer be Abram. Instead, you will be called Abraham, for you will be the father of many nations.
text_msg: Your name will no longer be Abram, but Abraham, meaning that 'I'm making you the father of many nations.'
text_nasb: 'No longer shall your name be called Abram, But your name shall be Abraham; For I will make you the father of a multitude of nations.
context: Genesis 17 marks a pivotal moment in God's covenant relationship with Abram. Previously, God promised Abram land and descendants (Genesis 12:1-3), but as time passed and Abram aged without a heir through Sarai, doubts may have crept in. Culturally, names in the Ancient Near East weren't mere labels; they embodied a person's essence, destiny, and even the power to influence their future. Changing a name was a significant act, indicating a profound shift in status or purpose. The chapter opens with God appearing to Abram at age ninety-nine, reinforcing the gravity of the impending promise and emphasizing divine initiative. This was not Abram’s idea, but a direct command and promise from God. The culture of the time placed immense value on offspring, particularly male heirs, for continuing the family line, inheriting property, and ensuring ancestor veneration. Abram's childlessness in his advanced age was therefore a source of significant societal pressure and personal concern. The covenant was sealed with the sign of circumcision, a physically demanding ritual intended as a constant reminder of God’s promise and Abraham’s commitment. The changing of Abram and Sarai’s names to Abraham and Sarah respectively demonstrates a transition into a new stage of their covenant relationship with God. This was not simply a symbolic gesture, but a declaration of their new identities as the progenitors of a multitude of nations, underscoring the magnitude and scope of God's promises.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 17:5 reveals several profound truths about God's nature and His relationship with humanity. First, it demonstrates God's sovereignty and power to redefine identity and destiny. Abram's new name, Abraham, meaning 'father of a multitude,' signified a radical shift from his previous reality, a childless man. This highlights God's ability to bring about what seems impossible from a human perspective. Second, the verse underscores the universal scope of God's plan of salvation. The promise of being the father of 'many nations' extends beyond the literal descendants of Abraham to encompass all who would believe in God through faith, as Paul elucidates in Romans 4:16-17. Abraham becomes a spiritual ancestor to both Jews and Gentiles who share his faith. Third, the name change signifies a new covenantal relationship. It's not just about physical descendants, but about a spiritual lineage marked by faith and obedience. This foreshadows the New Covenant established through Jesus Christ, where salvation is offered to all who believe, regardless of their ethnic background. Fourth, the verse illustrates the importance of faith in the face of adversity. Despite his age and Sarai's barrenness, Abraham had to embrace his new identity and believe in God's promise, even when it seemed logically improbable. His willingness to embrace this new identity showcases complete surrender and unwavering trust in the divine power.
application: In modern life, Genesis 17:5 offers several practical applications. Firstly, it challenges us to redefine our own identities in light of God's calling. Just as God renamed Abram, He often calls us to shed old identities based on past failures, societal expectations, or personal limitations, and embrace a new identity rooted in Christ. This may involve recognizing our inherent worth as children of God, acknowledging our spiritual gifts, and pursuing a purpose aligned with His will. Secondly, the verse encourages us to embrace a broader vision for our lives. Abraham's transformation from a potential patriarch of a small tribe to the father of many nations challenges us to think beyond our immediate circumstances and consider the global impact of our actions and decisions. This involves recognizing our responsibility to contribute to the well-being of others, advocate for justice, and share the Gospel with the world. Thirdly, it reinforces the importance of faith in the face of adversity. Like Abraham, we will encounter challenges and obstacles that seem insurmountable. However, we can draw strength from his example by trusting in God's promises, even when they seem improbable. This requires cultivating a habit of prayer, studying Scripture, and surrounding ourselves with a supportive community of believers who can encourage us during difficult times. Fourthly, it teaches the importance of embracing change. Abraham's name change symbolizes a willingness to step out of his comfort zone and embrace a new destiny. Similarly, we should be open to new opportunities, perspectives, and challenges that God presents to us, even if they seem daunting. This requires a spirit of humility, teachability, and a willingness to adapt to changing circumstances. Finally, we need to recognize our role as spiritual parents to those who are new to the faith, nurturing them and equipping them to become mature disciples of Christ. Just as Abraham became a father of many nations, we too are called to participate in the spiritual multiplication of God’s kingdom.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your unwavering promises and your power to redefine our lives. Just as you changed Abram's name and destiny, transform us into the people you created us to be. Help us to shed the old identities that hold us back and embrace the new identity we have in Christ. Grant us the faith to believe in your promises, even when they seem impossible. Give us a vision that extends beyond our immediate circumstances and enables us to make a positive impact on the world. Help us to be open to change and willing to embrace new opportunities you present. Equip us to be spiritual parents to others, nurturing them in their faith journey. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Changing Abram's name to Abraham was more than symbolic. It signified a new identity and destiny. It reflected God's promise to make him the 'father of a multitude,' solidifying the covenant and emphasizing the certainty of God's future blessings. Names in that time were linked to identity.
faqs.question: Q1: Why was it so important for God to change Abram's name?

faqs.answer: Paul explains in Romans that Abraham is the spiritual father of all who believe, regardless of their ethnicity. Faith, not lineage, is the key. Therefore, non-Jewish believers can also claim Abraham as their spiritual father through their faith in Jesus Christ.
faqs.question: Q2: How does Abraham becoming the father of many nations relate to non-Jewish believers?

faqs.answer: Abraham's acceptance of a new name shows his deep trust in God. It demonstrates that it's never too late to embrace God's calling and step into a new destiny, even when faced with seemingly insurmountable challenges and advanced age.
faqs.question: Q3: What can we learn from Abraham's willingness to accept a new name at such an old age?

faqs.answer: Reflect on areas where you feel limited by past mistakes or societal expectations. Claim your identity in Christ, recognizing your worth and potential. Believe God can transform you. Step out in faith, pursuing goals aligned with your divine purpose.
faqs.question: Q4: How can I apply the principle of a 'new identity' to my own life circumstances?

faqs.answer: The verse promotes a broader view. While nationalities exist, Abraham's role as 'father of many nations' highlights the unifying power of faith. It emphasizes a spiritual kinship transcends ethnicity, urging us to see all believers as part of one global family.
